com.versant.util
Class DBUtility

java.lang.Object
  com.versant.util.DBUtility

public class DBUtility
extends java.lang.Object

DBUtility provides the same functionality as provided by VERSANT utility functions.The functionality this class provides includes the ability to programmatically make, create, stop, start, remove, copy, reorganize databases. In addition using the APIs in this class it is possible to add volume to the database as well as read and write front end and back end profiles.

Constructor Detail

DBUtility

public DBUtility()
Method Detail

makeDB

public static void makeDB(java.lang.String dbName,
                          java.util.Properties properties)
Create a database directory for a group database, and create the database support files in the directory.

The options that can be specified through the properties object include:

Key ValueExplanation
-g"" Group database, the default
-p"" Personal database. -p and -g are mutually exclusive
-owneruserName Make user the owner of database directory. Note that this user is the DBA of the database. You can make someone else the owner only if you are logged in as the superuser.
-cpprofiledb Copy profiles from the specified db directory
-nofeprofile"" Do not create front-end profile
-logging"" Turn logging on (default)
-locking"" Turn locking on (default with -g)
-sglatch"" Turn multi_latch off
-passwordpassword set a DBA password on the database. Subsequent DBA access is only possible giving this password.

Example: 

 
 Properties p = new Properties();
 p.put("-g", " ");
 p.put("-owner", "ravi");
 p.put("-logging", " ");
 p.put("-password", "password");
 p.put("-feprofile", "c:\\osc\\testdb");
 p.put("-beprofile", "c:\\Versant\\db\\testdb\\profile.be");
 DBUtility.makeDB("javadb", p);

Note:

The "-password" option should be used if the user decides to associate a password with the DBA of the database. If a database is associated with a DBA password, then all DBA utility APIs on this database will require the password to be specified. If the database is not associated with a DBA password, then there is no change in the behavior of other DBA utility APIs.

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database to make
properties - a Properties object that contains the options to be used in making the database.

public static void makePDB(java.lang.String dbName,
                           java.lang.String password)
Create a database directory and the database support files in the directory for a personal database. Using this API, DBA will be associated with a password. Note: If a database is associated with a DBA password, then all DBA utility APIs on this database will require the password to be specified.

Parameters:
dbName - personal database to be made
password - DBA's password.

stopDB

public static void stopDB(java.lang.String dbName,
                          java.util.Properties options)
Stop the database dbname and remove all database resources in memory. For remote databases, append the node name to the database name using the syntax database@node. By default, a database will not be stopped if it is in use by any application.

To stop a database, you must be the user who started it, and thus the owner of its shared memory.

The options that can be specified through the properties object include:

Key ValueExplanation
-st"" Wait for active transactions to complete and then safely stop the database. This option blocks new transactions. If you attempt to start a new transaction while stopDB is waiting, an appropriate error will be returned to the application.
-s"" Wait for active updates to finish and then safely stop the database. This option blocks both new updates and new transactions. This option will wait for all active updates to finish before bringing the database down. If you try to start a new update while stopDB is waiting, an appropriate error will be returned to the application. This option will also wait for all active transactions to finish.
-f"" Immediately and forcibly stop the database. Please use the -f option with care.
-passwordpassword DBA's password
Note:

If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Example : 

 
 Properties properties = new Properties();
 properties..put("-f", "");
 DBUtility.stopDB(dbName,  properties);

Parameters:
dbName - database to be stopped
options - options to be passed

removeDB

public static void removeDB(java.lang.String dbName,
                            java.util.Properties options)
Stop the database dbname if it is running, destroy and remove all volumes of that database, and delete the respective entry from the system database identifier file osc-dbid. Without the -rmdir option the database directory and the files profile.be, .lock, etc. are not removed. I.e. the database directory is left in a state similar to the state after a makedb call.

The options that can be specified through the properties object are :

Key ValueExplanation
-f"" Forcibly stop and remove the database immediately even if it is currently running and other users are connected to it. Without the -f option, the database will not be removed if it is in use by an active transaction.
-rmdir"" Remove the database directory and all files in it as well as the database.
-passwordpassword DBA's password
Note:

If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Example: 

 
 Properties properties = new Properties();
 properties..put("-f", " ");
 DBUtility.removeDB(dbName , properties);

Parameters:
dbName - database to be removed
options - options to be passed

addVol

public static void addVol(java.lang.String dbName,
                          java.util.Properties p)
Increase storage capacity by creating and adding a volume to the database.

The parameters/options that can be specified through the properties object are listed below. A differentiation is made between parameters and options because the parameters are mandatory, and the options are optional.

Parameter Key ValueExplanation
-nvolname Logical name for the volume
-pvolpath Path of volume device/file
Option Key ValueExplanation
-svolsize Volume size, default to 128M. Indicate kilobytes with k or K and megabytes with m or M. For example: 1M, 1024k. If unit is not provided then it will throw 7035: UT_ER_VOLUME_SIZE - Invalid volume size.
-eextSize Extent size used for the volume. Default is the extent size specified in the back-end profile.
-i"" Preallocate and initialize the volume.
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Note:

If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Example: 

 
 Properties properties = new Properties();
 properties.put("-n", "sysvolume1");
 properties.put("-p", "/versant/db/mydb");
 properties.put("-e", "4");
 properties.put("-s", "2M");
 properties.put("-i", " ");
 DBUtility.addVol("myDB", properties);

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database to which a new volume has to be added.
p - a Properties object that contains the options to be used in adding volume to the database.

addVol

public static void addVol(java.lang.String dbName,
                          java.lang.String volName,
                          java.lang.String volPath,
                          java.lang.String volSize,
                          java.lang.String extSize,
                          boolean preAlloc)
Deprecated. As of JVI7.0, replaced by DBUtility.addVol(String,Properties)

Increase storage capacity by creating and adding a volume to the database.

Parameters:
dbName - database to be added volume
volName - new volume file name
volPath - new volume file path
volSize - new volume file size, default to 4M
extSize - extent size, default to use backend profile
preAlloc - pre-allocate and initialize volume

addVol

public static void addVol(java.lang.String dbName,
                          java.lang.String volName,
                          java.lang.String volPath)
Deprecated. As of JVI7.0, replaced by DBUtility.addVol(String,Properties)

Increase storage capacity by creating and adding a volume to the database. You can add volume to the database you are connecting with however you will not be able to use the space until you stop and start the database again.

Parameters:
dbName - database to be added volume
volName - new volume file name
volPath - new volume file path

createReplica

public static void createReplica(java.lang.String sourcedb,
                                 java.lang.String replicadb,
                                 boolean initialize)
Creates a database named replicaDB and replicates the objects in sourceDB to the newly created database.

Before calling this api the target database directory and support files must be created by calling DBUtility.makeDB or by running the command line utility makedb.

Parameters:
sourcedb - The name of the source database.
replicadb - The name of the replica database. parameter is true.
initialize - preallocate and initialize the database if this parameter is true.

createReplica

public static void createReplica(java.lang.String sourcedb,
                                 java.lang.String replicadb,
                                 java.util.Properties options)
Setup synchronous database replication between sourceDB and replicaDB

Before calling this API, the replica database directory and support files must be created by calling DBUtility.makeDB or by running the command line utility makedb.

The options that can be specified through the properties object are :

Key ValueExplanation
-nolock"" Ignore locks in source db
-i"" Preallocate and initialize the replica database
-nocreate"" The replica database is not created, i.e. an empty database with that name must exist.
-nocopy"" The contents of the source database is not copied to the replica database. The replica database must have the same contents than the source database. This is the case, if both databases are restored from a backup.
-threadsN Fork N threads for copying
-batchsizeM Copy M objects per transaction (default: 1000)
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Note:

Options -nocreate and -i cannot be used together.

If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Parameters:
sourcedb - The name of the source database
replicadb - The name of the replica database
options - Options to be passed

createReplica

public static void createReplica(java.lang.String sourcedb,
                                 java.lang.String replicadb,
                                 boolean initialize,
                                 java.lang.String password)
Creates a database named replicaDB and replicates the objects in sourceDB to the newly created database.

Before calling this method the replica database directory and support files must exist by calling DBUtility.makeDB, or by running the command line utility makedb.

Parameters:
sourcedb - The name of the source database.
replicadb - The name of the replica database.
initialize - if true preallocate and initialize the database
password - DBA's password.

removeReplica

public static void removeReplica(java.lang.String dbName,
                                 java.util.Properties options)
Remove Replica setup but don't necessarily remove the database.

The options that can be specified through the options object are :

Key ValueExplanation
-noremove"" Don't remove database. Just remove the replica information from the database.
-f"" Force removing of database
-rmdir"" Remove the database directory as well. Without this option the database directory is left in a state similar to the state after a makedb call.
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Parameters:
dbName - name of the replica database to be removed
options - options to be passed

reorgdb

public static void reorgdb(java.lang.String dbName)
Reorganize all data volumes for the database by rearranging objects to remove gaps in physical space. The purpose of reorgdb is to pack data so that the space is used more efficiently.

Caution: Any interruption such as a system failure or use of Ctrl-C, may result in an inconsistent database. It is strongly recommended that the database be backed up before using reorgdb to reorganize it.

The Sequence of steps involved in reorganizing a database is shown in the example below.

Example: 

 

  // set the database to single connection mode.
  DBUtility.dbInfo("db", -1");
  // stop the database
  DBUtility.stopDB("db");
  // run reorgdb
  DBUtility.reorgdb("db");

Parameters:
dbName - name of the database to be reorganized.

ftstoolDisablePolling

public static void ftstoolDisablePolling(java.lang.String dbName)
When Synchronous database replication (FTS) is used, this method can be used to turn automatic synchronization off. By default, if one database in a replication pair goes down, the other database forks a polling process to watch for its return. When the failed database returns, the polling process automatically resynchronizes the disrupted database with the database that did not go down.

This API can be used to disable the forking of a polling process on the specified database.

Note: Disabling the polling process is persistent. After calling this method, if the database is stopped and restarted the automatic synchronization will still be turned off.

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database that is being replicated.

ftstoolDisablePolling

public static void ftstoolDisablePolling(java.lang.String dbName,
                                         java.lang.String password)
When Synchronous database replication (FTS) is used, this method can be used to turn automatic synchronization off. By default, if one database in a replication pair goes down, the other database forks a polling process to watch for its return. When the failed database returns, the polling process automatically resynchronizes the disrupted database with the database that did not go down.

This API can be used to disable the forking of a polling process on the specified database.

Note: Disabling the polling process is persistent. After calling this method if the database is stopped and restarted the automatic synchronization will still be turned off.

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database that is being replicated.
password - DBA's password.

                                         java.util.Properties properties)

ftstoolEnablePolling

public static void ftstoolEnablePolling(java.lang.String dbName)
When Synchronous database replication (FTS) is used, this method can be used to turn automatic synchronization on. By Default if one database in a replication pair goes down, the other database forks a polling process to watch for its return. When the failed database returns, the polling process automatically resynchronizes the disrupted database with the database that did not go down.

This API can be used to enable the forking of a polling process on the specified database. Note: Enabling the polling process is persistent. After calling this method, if the database is stopped and restarted the automatic synchronization will still be on.

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database that is being replicated.

ftstoolDisableReplication

public static void ftstoolDisableReplication(java.lang.String dbName)
When Synchronous database replication (FTS) is used, this method can be used to break the replication of the databases in a FTS pair. If this API is used, the new transactions will be blocked and the current running transactions will be allowed to complete. Once the running transaction complete the database will be put into UNSTARTABLE mode and the database will be stopped.

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database that is being replicated.

ftstoolDisableReplication

public static void ftstoolDisableReplication(java.lang.String dbName,
                                             java.lang.String password)

If this API is used, the new transactions will be blocked and the current running transactions will be allowed to complete. Once the running transaction complete the database will be put into UNSTARTABLE mode and the database will be stopped.

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database that is being replicated.
password - DBA's password.

copyDB

public static void copyDB(java.lang.String sourceDB,
                          java.lang.String targetDB,
                          java.util.Properties options)
Copy the source database to target database.

The options that can be specified through the options object are :

Key ValueExplanation
-nolock"" Ignore locks in source db
-i"" Preallocate and initialize the target database
-nocreate"" The replica database is not created, i.e. an empty database with that name must exist.
-threadsN Fork N threads for copying
-batchsizeM Copy M objects per transaction (default: 1000)
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Note: Options -nocreate and -i cannot be used together. If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Parameters:
sourceDB - The name of the source database.
targetDB - The name of the target database.
options - options to be passed

dbid

public static void dbid()
Create osc-dbid file in Versant DB path

dbid

public static int dbid(java.lang.String dbName,
                       java.util.Properties options)
Create osc-dbid file in $VERSANT_DBID path at node $VERSANT_DBID_NODE, or create / remove the database entry from the osc-dbid file.

The options that can be specified through the options object are :

Key ValueExplanation
-N"" Create an osc-dbid file. Parameter dbName needs to be empty.
-c"" Create an entry in osc-dbid file for the database dbName.
-d"" Remove the database entry dbName from the osc-dbid file
-Cdbid Create an entry in osc-dbid file for the database dbName and set the database id as dbid. Caution: Use this option with great care! Don't use a dbid already in use by another database. Keep in mind that a database id might have changed during the lifetime of a database. So it is not enough to inspect the ids in use with the dblist tool. Please refer to the administration manual for further details: look at the dbid and setdbid command line tools. dbid is an integer between 1 and 0xFF7F, or decimal 65407.
-ttype Specify the type of the database

1 - for personal database

2 - for group database

Can only be used with -c or -C option. Default database type is group.

-r"" Print the database id of the database dbName

Example: 

 
 Properties properties = new Properties();
 properties.put("-C", "50");
 properties.put("-t", "1");
 DBUtility.dbid("myDB", properties);

Note: The "-c" and "-C" are advanced options and should be used with great care. If they are to be used then please ensure that you give a subsequent call to DBUtility.setDBID with the dbid which has just been created.

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database for which an entry should be created or deleted from the osc-dbid file. ( Empty String if using -N option ).
options - a Properties object that contains the options to be used.
Returns:
the dbid for the specified database. For -N option it will be 0.

dbUser

public static void dbUser(java.lang.String dbName,
                          java.util.Properties properties)
Add, delete users of a database dbName or change the password for an existing user. For a remote database, append the node name to the database name using the syntax database@node.

The options that can be specified through the properties object are :

Command ValueExplanation
-add"" Add a user to the database access list. You must also supply -n or -P option.
-delete"" Delete a user from the database access list. You must also supply -n or -P option.
-chpasswd"" Change the password of a user. You must also supply -n option.
If you use -add or -delete, you must substitute one of the following for option.
Option ValueExplanation
-nusername User name. An error is raised if the given username is not found in the database when you are doing a delete.
-P"" Change public access. When public access is on, all database users can access the database. When public access is off, only users in the user list can access the database. To turn public access on, use -add -P. To turn public access off, use -delete -P.
If you use -add you may also use the following option.
Option ValueExplanation
-mr/rw Set database access mode for the user(s) specified with -n or -P. Read/write access is the default.
-passwdpassword The password of a user provided when adding a user to a group database.
-opasswdoldPassword The old password to be specified when changing the user's password.
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Note :

To add a user to a database, you must be the owner of the database and the database must be a group database. To delete a user from a database, you must own the database. You cannot delete the owner of the database. If you have access to a database but are not the owner, you can't change the access privileges of others. After a database has been created, you can change its ownership by changing the ownership of its database directory. If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Example: 

 
    Properties p = new Properties();
    p.put ("-add", "");
    p.put ("-n" , "user");
    p.put ("-passwd" , "password");
    DBUtility.dbUser("javadb",p);

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database
properties - a Properties object that contains the commands / options to be used with dbuser.

removeDBUser

public static void removeDBUser(java.lang.String dbName,
                                java.lang.String userName)

dbInfo

public static java.lang.String dbInfo(java.lang.String dbName,
                                      java.lang.String option)
Set the mode of the database per parameters specified in option.

The options that can be specified through the option string are listed below. Note that all but -password are mutually exclusive. If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password as additional option.

Option ValueExplanation
-m Set multi-user mode
-0 Set unstartable mode
-1 Set DBA-only single-connection mode
-d Set DBA-only multi-connection mode
-p Print existing database mode
-c Create a new .lock file
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Parameters:
dbName - database to set mode
option - parameter to set mode

compareDb

public static CompareDBResult[] compareDb(java.lang.String dbName,
                                          java.lang.String dbName2,
                                          java.util.Properties properties)
Compare the databases dbName and dbName2 and return an array of CompareDBResult objects.

The options that can be specified through the properties object are :

Option ValueExplanation
-value"" Compare object values
-force"" Forces the database into a single user mode
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Note: If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Example 1: 

 
 Example1:
        Properties p = new Properties();
        DBUtility.compareDb("jdb",jdb2,p);

Example 1: 

 
        Properties p = new Properties();
        p.put ("-value", " ");
        p.put ("-force", " ");
        DBUtility.compareDb("jdb",jdb2,p);

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database to be compared
dbName2 - Name of the database to be compared
properties - a Properties object that contains the options to be used in comparing the databases.
Returns:
an array of CompareDBResult objects. Currently it returns only one instance of CompareDBResult class that gives information about whether the databases are identical or not. If databases are not identical then it sets the oid field to the first Loid which differs between the two databases.

                             java.util.Properties options)

Parameters:
dbName - database to be converted
options - options to be passed. There are no options to pass to convertDB.

Example : 

 
 DBUtility.convertDB(dbName, null);
Note : Argument option is added for the future purpose.

compareDBs

public static DBCompareResult compareDBs(java.lang.String dbName1,
                                         java.lang.String dbName2,
                                         java.util.Properties options)
Compare the databases dbName1 and dbName2 and confirms that the logical object identifiers for the objects in the databases are the same, and display the logical object identifiers that differs depending on the options supplied.

The options that can be specified through the options object are :

Option ValueExplanation
-value"" Compare object values as well as object identifiers and display the first logical object identifier for objects with non-equal values.
-force"" Forces the database into a single user mode
-fullcompare"" Display list of loids of objects which are different in two databases. If this option is not specified only first differed loid will be returned.
-classesclassName Compare objects of only the specified class(es). For multiple classes use space as delimiter.
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Note: If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Example: 

 
  Properties p = new Properties();
  DBCompareResult result;
  p.put("-value", "");
  p.put("-classes", "com.vin.Account com.vin.AccountHolder");
  java.util.Vector loidsDb ;
  java.util.Vector loidsDb2 ;

  try
  {
    result = DBUtility.compareDBs("db1", "db2", p);
  }
  catch (com.versant.fund.VExecption vex)
  {
    vex.printStackTrace();
  }

  if(result.getStatus() == com.versant.fund.Constants.DATABASES_ARE_IDENTICAL)
  {
    System.out.println("Databases are identical");
  }
  else if ( result.status == com.versant.fund.Constants.SOME_OBJECTS_ARE_DIFFERENT)
  {
    System.out.println("Databases are different");
  }
  else
  {
    System.out.println("Error");
  }

Parameters:
dbName1 - Name of the database to be compared
dbName2 - Name of the database to be compared
options - Properties object that contains the options to be used in comparing the databases.
Returns:
an instance of com.versant.util.DBCompareResult class that gives information about whether the databases are identical or not.

If both databases are identical, the DBCompareResult's attribute "status" is set to an integer constant defined as "DATABASES_ARE_IDENTICAL" and vectors loidsDB1, loidsDB2 and loidsByValue in DBCompareResult class will be set to null. If not, the DBCompareResult attribute status is set to an integer constant defined as "SOME_OBJECTS_ARE_DIFFERENT" and the vector loidsDB1, loidsDB2 and loidsByValue gets populated with the differed loids depending on options supplied.

loidsDB1 vector contains loids in dbName1 and not in dbName2. Valid only in case of -fullcompare, null otherwise.

loidsDB2 vector contains loids in dbName2 and not in dbName1. Valid only in case of -fullcompare, null otherwise.

loidsByValue vector contains loids that are different in value in both the databases, null otherwise.

For remote databases use dbName@node syntax. This method is useful in comparing the contents of a primary and synchronous replication database. Before using this, you must set both databases to single user mode in order to compare stable database states. The second comparison database, db2, must be a group database.

In case VSL_MEM_NOMEM error com.versant.fund.VException will be thrown mentioning use com.versant.util.DBUtility.compareDBsAdvanced method. In case of any other error appropriate exception will be thrown to the application.

compareDBsAdvanced

public static int compareDBsAdvanced(java.lang.String dbName,
                                     java.lang.String dbName2,
                                     java.util.Properties options,
                                     java.lang.String fileName)
Compare the databases dbName and dbName2 and confirms that the logical object identifiers for the objects in the databases are the same and stores the differed logical object identifiers into the file specified, depending on the options supplied.

Note : If there is no difference, then an empty file will be created. Also note that if a file with the name already exists, it will be overwritten.

The following is a snapshot view of the file : 

 516.0.1085 1
 516.0.1086 2
 516.0.1092 1
 516.0.1055 3

Please note the format of the file above. The first is a loid, followed by a space which is then followed by an integer flag which indicates the type of difference.

The significance of the flags are indicated below :

Flag Explanation
1 Loid is in dbName and not in dbName2
2 Loid is in dbName2 and not in dbName
3 Loid is in both databases, but the object is different in value

The options that can be specified through the options object are :

Option ValueExplanation
-value"" Compare object values as well as object identifiers and display the first logical object identifier for objects with non-equal values.
-force"" Forces the database into a single user mode
-fullcompare"" Display list of loids of objects which are different in two databases. If this option is not specified only first differed loid will be returned.
-classesclassName Compare objects of only the specified class(es). For multiple classes use space as delimiter.
-passwordpassword DBA's password

Note :

-classes option is a must for this method.

If the database is associated with a DBA password, then you have to specify the password.

Example: 

 
  Properties p = new Properties();
  DBCompareResult result;
  p.put("-value", "");
  p.put("-classes", "com.vin.Account com.vin.AccountHolder");

  try
  {
    result = DBUtility.compareDBsAdvanced("db1", "db2", p, "/tmp/vin/cmpdb");
  }
  catch (com.versant.fund.VExecption vex)
  {
    vex.printStackTrace();
  }

  if(result.getStatus() == com.versant.fund.Constants.DATABASES_ARE_IDENTICAL)
  {
    System.out.println("Databases are identical");
  }
  else if ( result.status == com.versant.fund.Constants.SOME_OBJECTS_ARE_DIFFERENT)
  {
    System.out.println("Databases are different");
  }
  else
  {
    System.out.println("Error");
  }

Parameters:
dbName - Name of the database to be compared
dbName2 - Name of the database to be compared
options - Properties object that contains the options to be used in comparing the databases.
fileName - Absolute file name where you wish to store results.
Returns:
status, a integer constant that gives information about whether the databases are identical or not. If both databases are identical, it returns an integer constant defined as "DATABASES_ARE_IDENTICAL" and if not, returns integer constant defined as "SOME_OBJECTS_ARE_DIFFERENT". In case of any other error appropriate exception will be thrown to the application.
